newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Komercni seeks to raise GDR limit - paper.
newsitem.headline: Komercni seeks to raise GDR limit - paper.

text.p: Komercni Banka a.s., the Czech Republic's largest commercial bank, is seeking central bank permission to increase the maximum amount of Global Depositary Receipts (GDRs) it may issue, economic daily Hospodarske Noviny reported on Thursday.
"We would welcome having the current 10 percent limit raised to 12 percent," the paper quoted Komercni deputy director Petr Budinsky as saying.
Last year, the central bank granted Komercni permission to issue up to 10 percent of its shares as GDRs.

Komercni initially converted 3.2 percent of its shares into GDRs for foreign investors, and has gradually increased the amount through subsequent coversions. Komercni has not said how much of the 10 percent limit it has used.
The GDRs are held by the Bank of New York.
"We have received an application (for raising the GDR limit) from the Bank of New York and (our) supervisors are working on it," central bank spokesman Martin Svehla told the paper.
Neither central bank officials nor Komercni officials were immediately available for comment.
According to central bank regulations, foreigners may not hold shares in any Czech bank unless they have received permission from the central bank.
The Komercni GDRs have no voting rights, and the issue of the securities has not raised the bank's basic capital.
Budinsky said that if the limit were raised, shares would come from the open market and not the state's holdings in the bank. The state still holds 48.7 percent in Komercni.
